q: What are the symptoms of altitude sickness?
a: The symptoms of altitude sickness include a headache, loss of appetite, feeling or being sick, feeling tired or exhausted, dizziness, and difficulty sleeping. In more serious cases, symptoms can become life-threatening.

q: What should I do if I get altitude sickness?
a: If you experience altitude sickness, it is important to rest at the same altitude until you feel better. You can also take anti-sickness medicine or painkillers to relieve the symptoms. If your condition does not improve after a day or worsens, it is advised to go to a lower altitude.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for altitude sickness?
a: You should seek immediate medical help if you or someone else at a high altitude experiences severe symptoms of altitude sickness, such as confusion, balance problems, hallucinations, difficulty breathing, coughing up frothy or bloody spit, blue or grey skin, or extreme sleepiness.

q: What treatments are available for altitude sickness?
a: Resting usually helps alleviate altitude sickness symptoms, but medication may be prescribed to relieve symptoms. In severe cases, steroid medicine, medicine to lower blood pressure, or oxygen therapy may be necessary.

q: How can I reduce the risk of altitude sickness?
a: To reduce the risk of altitude sickness, it is recommended to ascend slowly, spend a few days at lower altitudes before going higher, rest regularly, stay hydrated, and avoid alcohol. Consulting with a healthcare professional may also be helpful, especially if you have had altitude sickness before.
